segments.content: A nice release with some new features that Vercel devs had already given us a preview of. The new Metadata API is useful for SEO, works well with SSR streaming, server components and the new app directory. The new Route Handlers seem to have a good usability: co-located, just export the HTTP verb. Particularly excited by the new features around MDX (Rust compiler, Server Components): that should make Next.js content sites much lighter and faster to use. If I understand correctly, Next.js starts using a TypeScript codegen step for typed links (in addition to the TypeScript plugin). Turbopack compatibility with Webpack loaders can make it easier to adopt the new bundler.

segments.content: The biggest surprise for me is the introduction of a cache API directly integrated to `fetch()`: allows a bit the same thing as ISR but with a finer granularity, at the component level, for each request. There is even a tagging system. Next.js remains portable: the cache can be hosted on your own infrastructure, or use a local LRU cache. Of course, this is optimized for deploying on Vercel. A dedicated article gives more details and explains the limits of the ISR model: [Vercel Cache API: A progressive cache, integrated with Next.js](https://vercel.com/blog/vercel-cache-api-nextjs-cache). See also the [thread of Sebastian MarkbÃ¥ge](https://twitter.com/sebmarkbage/status/1628845420121128965).

segments.content: Signals remained the trending topic of the week. I suggest you read for yourself the many discussions that took place on Twitter:
segments.sourceMdx: Signals remained the trending topic of the week. I suggest you read for yourself the many discussions that took place on Twitter:

segments.content:
* Andrew Clark [clarifies his position](https://twitter.com/acdlite/status/1628811935088013314) and is [not closed to introducing signals into React](https://twitter.com/acdlite/status/1626590880126889984). The React Forget compiler [could compile to signals](https://twitter.com/acdlite/status/1628930249718202369).
* MiÅ¡ko Hevery [explains](https://twitter.com/mhevery/status/1628556944318550016) how signals avoid perf problems on the drilling props.
* Evan You [prefers](https://twitter.com/youyuxi/status/1629636673519894528) an understandable mutable model to an immutable model that leaks.
* Devon Govett [reminds us](https://twitter.com/devongovett/status/1629540226589663233) why "unidirectional data flow" was adopted and points out some problems with signals.
* Jordan Walke [mentions](https://twitter.com/jordwalke/status/1629663133039214593) that they considered using a reactive model when React was created. Rejected because it changed the semantics of the language.
* Dan Abramov [explains](https://twitter.com/dan_abramov/status/1629872956288512007) that the user expects to see the same interface for the same data. He [explains](https://twitter.com/dan_abramov/status/1629539600489119744) the value of using "raw values" (not wrapped in any container).
* [My position](https://twitter.com/sebastienlorber/status/1630264713845039104): I largely share the same views as the React team and think we need to continue to innovate on the current model, despite Signals looking attractive in the short term. I hope that eventually JavaScript will support better the immutable model, and that the React Forget compiler is only a transitional step.

segments.content: Reanimated 3.0 has just been released in a stable version, with a new Shared Elements Transitions feature ([demo](https://twitter.com/swmansion/status/1630590156255240193)). It is now possible to use shared values in inline styles. The library has been rewritten to improve performance, DX and prepare for the arrival of new features. It is compatible with Fabric and the Reanimated 2 API to facilitate the upgrade, but the Reanimated 1 API has been removed.
